items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
Senate Bill 850 was recently introduced by Senator Marty Block.  This bill would change existing law to authorize a limited number of  California Community Colleges to establish and provide one baccalaureate degree pilot program per campus per district with an expiration timeframe of 8 years.  
	 
Contained within the text of the attached bill identified as document "B" are a number of findings that warrant the support of SB 850.  
Language within the attached resolution identified as document "A" supports several of these findings and additionally asserts our District's priority to underserved students and to ensure that these students will not be adversely impacted or displaced by baccalaureate-seeking candidates.  For this latter reason, we are recommending that SB 850 be amended to include language that will provide for an accountability measure to protect the "lower quartile" of students who could be negatively impacted.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution No. 022514-1 in support of SB 850 introduced by Senator Marty Block (Baccalaureate degrees at community colleges)

items.item_details:
In development of the 2025 Facilities Master Plan (FMP) for Evergreen Valley College (EVC), data related to the Evergreen Fault adjacent to campus was updated and depicted on the FMP site plan.  That data and plan identified portions of the EVC campus to be within a State-designated Alquist-Priolo Special Study Zone.  California Geologic Survey Publication 42, “Fault Rupture Hazard Zones in California” requires designation of an area within 50 feet of an active fault as a no-build zone.  This requirement places the Roble and Acacia buildings at EVC within this no-build zone.
	 
Following this identification in November 2011, Evergreen Valley College considered options for the replacement or relocation of the affected buildings.  While application for state funding for both buildings could have been submitted, there was no state funding for buildings and a state-wide bond would have been necessary to establish that funding.  This option, and the inability to commence design and construction until funding was identified, would have prevented EVC from taking any major action until at least 2015.  A second option was to forego state funding completely and build complete replacement buildings under the Bond.  Under this scenario the new buildings would have been available for occupancy in early 2016, but would have depleted funds for other important aspects of the Facility Master Plan.  A third option was to address the Acacia Building and start its replacement buildings (South Campus and Automotive Technology) and to request state funding on replacing the Roble Building.  This would provide replacement for Acacia in 2016 and for Roble in 2018.  This was the selected option, and funding requests for the Engineering/Applied Technology were submitted through an Initial Project Proposal (IPP) in July 2012 and a Final Project Proposal (FPP) in July 2013.  
	 
At the same time, numerous actions were required of the District and the Board by the Education Code and Field Act as a result of the fault identification.  At its November 12, 2013 meeting the Board received information that updated the status of those required actions. (See attached presentation from that meeting.)  These included:
Prepare cost estimates to address replacement or relocation of affected buildings – performed in June 2011 and Oct 2013
Notify the State and apply for funding – notified in July 2012 and July 2013
Board notification – notified in November 2011 and November 2013
Engineering study of building safety – completed by Thornton Tomasetti in October 2013
	 
The key elements from that November 12, 2013 presentation were a finding that Roble and Acacia are, from an engineering standpoint, considered unsafe.  (The definition of “unsafe” is driven by Education Code 81162.)  Further, legal counsel has stated that, “The provisions of the Education Code … and the Field Act itself, do not require the District to stop using existing school buildings which have, by virtue of new information, been determined to be unsafe in the event of earthquake.”  And the engineers have noted that “There is no code or law in effect that mandates that buildings designed and constructed according to a previous version of the code need to be brought into conformance with the current code, provided that there is no change in use or alteration that includes a significant increase in load or decrease in structural capacity. So despite the fact that the Acacia and Roble Clusters do not meet current code, continued use of these buildings is allowed by code…..”
	 
Since the November 12, 2013 Board meeting, the college has presented the circumstances to the faculty and staff through participatory governance and campus forums, and to student government.  The engineer’s report, the schedules for retrofit and new building construction, and the opinions of legal counsel were all presented and discussed.  The various options were presented and additional options identified.  At the conclusion of these meetings, with all considerations made, it is the consensus of the College and the President’s recommendation that Roble and Acacia remain in service without modification.  The South Campus and Automotive Technology projects will commence construction in 2014, which will provide replacement space for the majority of sections now using Acacia.  The college will continue pursuit of supportive State funding for the Engineering & Technology project, which will be constructed on the site of Roble.  Should State funding not materialize, the college will develop alternative plans to continue toward development of that building.

items.item_details: At the February 11, 2014, Governing Board Meeting, the Board reviewed a draft Board Governance Policies document and compared those policies with the current Chapter Two, Board of Trustees, policies. After this discussion, it was evident that a lot of work still needed to be done with the merging of these policies. Therefore, the Board appointed a Task Force, composed of Trustees Lease, Ho and Cruz to continue the comparison work between the governing policies and Chapter Two policies. The Task Force met on Wednesday, February 19, 2014, and made a lot of progress with this work. At this meeting, the Task Force will provide an update on the work they have completed and the next steps of the process. The Board will provide feedback on the Task Force report and also engage in further discussion on governance policy development.

items.item_details: At the February 11, 2014, Governing Board Meeting, President Lease reviewed a draft template document outlining the various board committees, the composition and charges of those committees, and a proposed status for each committee. He requested that Board Committee Chairs meet with their respective committee members, review the governing policy on Board Committee Structure and fill out the template document. The objective of this work would be to determine the product and outcome of each board committee. The purpose of this agenda item is to allow the Board Committee Chairs to provide this report to the Board.
